Abstract Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been performed to evaluate the geometries and electronic properties of nickel decorated aluminum phosphide (AlP) nano-cages. At the lowest coverage of our system (one Ni per one Al12P12), four adsorption sites (P1-P4) of Ni on AlP nano-cage are studied. Band structures, binding energies, total density of states, natural bond orbital (NBO) charges, and electron density differences of Ni-adsorbed Al12P12 nanocages are studied for each adsorption site. We found that three orientations (P1, P2, and P3) show electron transfer from the Ni to Al12P12 whereas one orientation (P4) has reverse direction of electron transfer. The adsorption energies of Ni on AlP nano-cage are -136.7, - 108.5, -102.7, and -99.4 kcal mol-1 for P4, P3, P1 and P2, respectively. Formation of new AlNi and P-Ni bonds is observed concomitant with the dissociation of some Al-P bonds of the nano-cage.
Key words: Nano-cage, Al12P12, Ni adsorption, density functional theory, thin solid film 1. Introduction
Nano-structure such as nanotubes, fullerens and nanoclusters have gained great interest because of their high surface/volume ratio. These nano-materials find applications in adsorption [1,2], transistors [3], catalysts [4], sensors[5], and biomedical [6]. Research is carried out extensively not only to design new materials but also to enhance the properties of the existing materials through structural modifications. Recently, we have demonstrated enhanced adsorption properties of nitrogen [7-8], aluminum [9-13] and platinum [14,15] doped graphene over the pristine graphene. Recently high consideration has been focused on (XY)n nanostructures [16] where X and Y are group III and V elements. These structures may include sheet or fullerene like nano-cages [17]. Among fullerene like nano-cages, X12Y12, X16Y16, X24Y24 and X28Y28 are particularly

interesting and appealing due to their large band gap semi-conductor properties [18]. Al12N12 and Al12P12, B12N12, and B12P12 are four chief fullerene-like cages in this class due to their particular physical properties [18, 19]. In recent paper, we investigated the adsorption of guanine molecule on the surfaces of these cages. We found high degree of adsorption in the case of Al12N12 and Al12P12 [20]. There are many reports on different AlmPn nanoclusters [21–22]. Al12P12 nanostructure has attained scientists' consideration because of its low electron attraction, large band gap and exceptional physical and chemical properties [23, 24].
Metals adsorbed on the surface of nano-cage enhances catalytic and adsorption properties
[25-27]. Besides the above mentioned nano-cages, the composite metal-nanocages have potential applicants in different areas such as optical and magnetic devices, and catalysis [28]. For example there are several first-principles theoretical reports on metal interaction with AlN and GaN [28-33]. Zhang et al. [28] used DFT method to search for the probability of bare- and Ni-adsorbed AlN nano-cages for hydrogen storage. They found that in bare AlN, each Al atom is able to adsorb one H2 molecule whereas in the Ni adsorbed AlN, the Ni atom has been found to adsorb up to three hydrogen molecules. Pana et. al. [29] investigated the effect of Si-doping on AlN films. They showed that Si is a potential nonmagnetic dopant for preparing diluted magnetic semiconductor films. In another theoretical study, Cui et al [33] have shown that Cr atom has strong tendency to segregate to form Cr-N-Cr bonded embedded clusters. To the best of our knowledge there is no report in the literature on adsorption of metal on Al12P12, an important spherical form of AlP. We report here the effect of Ni adsorption on the geometries and electronic properties of AlP nano-cage. Geometries, electronic structure, optimization parameters including binding energy calculation, bond lengths, charge analysis, dipole moments (DM), and band gaps of the Ni decorated Al12P12 nano-cage at different adsorption positions have been deeply investigated.

sections.heading: 2. Computational methods
sections.text:
In the present work, we considered the adsorption properties of the Ni on Al12P12
clusters. All the geometrical optimizations are performed without any constraints
using Gaussian 09 program package [34] at B3LYP/6-31G (d,p) level of theory. 6-
31G is a suitable basis set as it has been used for different calculation on nano-cages [24, 27]. Also [B3LYP is a popular functional that has been commonly used for nanotube structures
[24, 27, 35]. For full optimization of the applied systems, Ni is allowed to move
freely across the surface of cluster. The adsorption energy of Ni on the Al12P12 at different positions is specified through as follow:

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Figure 1. Relaxed structure of Al12P12 (left) and it's MEP (right). A1 and A2 correspond to the four- and six- membered rings, d1 is the bond length of Al-N (between A1 and A2 rings), and d2 is the bond length of Al-P (between two A2 rings). A1 is four-membered ring and A2 is sixmembered ring The relaxed structure of free AlP nano-cage is depicted in Figure 1. The geometric parameters for optimized geometries in this study agree with the already reported data [19]. The AlP nano-cage is a large band gap semiconductor material. A nickel (Ni) atom is decorated on the surface of the nano-cage in order to modify the electronic properties. Geometries of nickel decorated AlP nano-cages are very important since the electronic

properties are highly dependent on the orientation of the nickel atom on the surface of the nano-cage. There are potentially six different sites on the surface of AlP nanocage where Ni can be placed: M@P, M@Al, M@r4, M@r6, M@b66 and M@b64. M@P and M@Al are the orientations where nickel is placed on top of phosphorus and aluminum atoms, respectively. M@r4 and M@r6 are the orientations where nickel atom is placed above four- membered (A1) and six- membered ring (A2), respectively. M@b66 and M@b64 are the orientations where nickel atom is placed on bond shared between two six- membered ring (d2), and a sixand four- membered ring (d1). Although, there are six geometries possible but during the process of optimizations, only four different geometries were obtained which are here labeled as P1 (M@b64), P2 (M@b66), P3 (M@r4) and P4 (M@r6). The interaction energies for P1-P3 orientations are in the range of -99 to -109 kcal mol-1, whereas the interaction energy of Ni with AlP nano-cage in P4 is -136.7 kcal mol-1. The adsorption energies of nickel on Al12P12 are considerably higher than the adsorption energies of nickel on Al12N12 (2.22 eV or 51.2 kcal mol -1), reported by Zhang et al. [26].
The high interaction energy of Ni in all orientation is indicative of chemisorption. It is
obvious from the data that interaction energies are dependent on the mode of interaction of Ni with the nano-cage. For example, in P1 and P2, where the nickel atom is located on a bond, the interaction energies are relatively less. The interaction energies for Ni with AlP in P1 and P2 geometries are -102.7 and -99.4 kcal mol-1, and this can be easily correlated with the distance of Ni from the nano-cage. The shorter distance of Ni with AlP nano-cage in P1 (1.59Å) compared to P2 (1.63 Å) results in higher interaction energy. Comparable interaction energies in P1 and P2 orientation clearly illustrate that the effect of ring size of the AlP nanocage is negligible.

For both orientations (P1 and P2), only two atoms (one aluminum and phosphorus each) interact with nickel however, the number of atoms of the nano-cage interacting with nickel increase to four and six in P3 and P4, respectively. The greater coordination of nickel in P3 and P4 results in higher interaction energies. The larger cavity size of six-membered ring causes the nickel atom to become co-planar with the six-membered ring (see Fig 2); whereas no such effect is seen for four- membered ring in P3. Decoration of nickel on the surface of AlP nano-cage also results in change in the geometric parameters of the nano-cage. The effect on the geometric parameters is also dependent on the nature of interaction. For P1 and P2, a more pronounced effect on d1 and d2 is observed compared to P3 and P3 because the former pair has nickel atom interacting on a bond. The bond distances d1 (b64) and d2 (b66) are 2.34 Å and 2.29 Å for pure AlP nano-cage. For P1, the d1 increases to 2.79 Å whereas d2 decreases to 2.31 Å. On the other hand, d2 increases to 2.60 Å whereas d1 remains also unaffected for P2. Nickel atom in P3 and P4 is in the center of a four- and six- membered ring, respectively, and it is not expected to affect d1 and d2 to any considerable extent. For P3, d1 and d2 are 2.43 Å and 2.28 Å, respectively whereas the corresponding geometric parameters in P4 are 2.38 and 2.31 Å. The P2 geometry contains a nickel atom on a bond shared between two six- membered ring whereas the P1 has the nickel atom on a bond between a six and a four-membered ring. The four- membered ring in P1 geometry opens up to an envelope like five- membered ring upon adsorption of a nickel atom which results in decrease in the strain. This probably explains why the adsorption energy for P1 is higher than P2. For P3 and P4 geometries, the nickel atom is at the center of ring and all atoms are coordinating to the metal atom. The Ni-P and Ni-Al bond distances are 2.46 and 2.26 Å in P4 geometries whereas the corresponding bond lengths in P3 geometry are 2.16 and 2.20 Å respectively.

Interaction of nickel atom with AlP nano-cage results in significant changes in the dipole moment, molecular electrostatic potential (MEP) and QNBO. Dipole moments and QNBO are given Table 1 whereas MEP is given in Figure 3. The dipole moment of pure AlP nano-cage is zero which can be expected for a symmetrical structure. However, this dipole moment changes significantly by decoration of a nickel atom on the surface. Dipole moments for P1 and P2 geometries are 3.24 and 3.87 Debye, respectively which are significantly higher than the dipole moments for P3 (1.30 D) and P4 (1.06 D) geometries. The direction of dipole moments in all geometries (P1-P4) is from the center of the nano-cage to the metal atom. Interestingly, the dipole moments are shown to have inverse relationship with the binding energies. This inverse relationship can be explained based on the distance of nickel from the nano-cage. The large distance in P2, although results in lower binding energies, but causes larger dipole moment due to large vector. Alternatively, the dipole moments of the nickel decorated nao-cages can also be explained by charge separation between Ni and the nano-cage. The nickel atom is more positively charged in P2 geometry, and QNBO is +0.51. The charge on nickel decreases to +0.49 in P1, which further decreases to +0.19 in P3. The nickel atom in P4 has negative charge which illustrates

the direction of dipole moment. The decrease in positive charge on nickel can be explained through the number and distance of coordinating atoms to the metal center. Positive charge on the metal atom decreases with decrease in the distance with coordinating atoms (phosphorus in this case). Moreover, positive charge on the metal atom decreases with increase in the number of coordinating atoms. In P1 and P2, only one phosphorus atom coordinates with the nickel atom where in P3 and P4, two and three phosphorus atoms coordinate to nickel, respectively. A transition from positive to negative charge is observed when three phosphorus atoms are coordinated to nickel. The change in electronic structure around nickel can also be seen in MEP. For P1 and P2, the nickel atom has positive potential whereas the atoms in the nano-cage have almost neutral potential. Only a slight negative potential can be realized on phosphorus atoms. In P3, the positive potential on nickel decreases (compared to P1 and P2) and is shifted to aluminum atoms in the nano-cage (light blue color). A marked change is observed for P4 where the nickel atom in the center of a six- membered ring is almost neutral whereas the aluminum atoms in the nano-cage have high positive potential. The different behavior of nickel in P4 is probably due to different electronic environment around nickel compared to those in P1-P3. The nickel atom in P4 is coordinated to three phosphorus atoms (although at slightly larger distances) which renders the metal less electron deficient (or somewhat electron rich).

Frontier molecular orbital analysis and density of states Next, the frontier molecular orbitals are analyzed to study the effect of adsorption of nickel on the nano-cage. The frontier molecular orbitals are given in Figure 4 whereas the energies of HOMO (EHOMO), LUMO (ELUMO), Fermi level (EFL), HOMO-LUMO gap (Eg) for different systems are given in Table 2. Nickel is a metal with very small HOMO-LUMO gap (0.22 eV). The AlP nano-cage, on the other hand, is a semi conductor with a band gap of 3.39 eV. The HOMO and LUMO of AlP nano-cages have energies of -6.75 and -3.36 eV, respectively. Adsorption of nickel atom on the surface of AlP nano-cage brings about quite significant changes in frontier molecular orbitals regarding their densities and energies. Adsorption of

nickel atom on the surface of AlP nano-cage, in general, increases the energies of HOMOs without much affecting the energies of LUMOs. The energies of HOMOs in P1 and P2 geometries are almost comparable; -5.73 and -5.76 eV, respectively. Similarly, the energies of LUMO in P1 and P2 are also very comparable (-3.25 and -3.26 eV). The similar energies of HOMO and LUMO in P1 and P2 lead to similar band gaps: 2.48 and 2.50 eV, respectively. These band gaps are about 0.9 eV lower than the pure AlP nano-cage. The HOMO-LUMO gap for P4 geometry is also 2.47 eV (about 0.9 eV lower than the pure AlP nano-cage) however; the energies of HOMO and LUMO are different than those from P1 and P2 geometries. In P4 geometry, the energies of HOMO and LUMO are -5.96 and -3.49 eV, respectively. The effect of nickel decoration is more pronounced in P3 geometry where the HOMO-LUMO gap is reduced to 2.25 eV. Change is Eg for metal doped AlP nano-cage is expected to cause significant changes in electrical conductivity because the electrical conductivity of bulk material is mainly determined by Eg (for bulk materials). Relationship between conductivity and Eg can be given by the following equation [43].

The HOMO-LUMO outlook of free AlP and Ni-adsorbed modes at different positions Next, the HOMO and LUMO orbitals are analyzed for P1-P4 geometries in order to rationalize the different behavior of nickel decoration on the band gap and Fermi levels. As shown in Figure 4, the shapes of HOMO and LUMO orbitals are similar in P1 and P2 geometries. The HOMO is located mainly on the nickel atom whereas the LUMO has density uniformly distributed over all atoms. The coordination of phosphorus atoms of the nano-cage with transition metal pushes the outer d electrons of Ni to become more diffuse excess

electron which increases the energy level of newly formed HOMO. The location of densities of HOMO on metal center is supportive to our notion. For P1 and P2, only one phosphorus atom of the nano-cage interacts with the metal atom whereas in P3 and P4, more than one phosphorus atoms from the nano-cage interact with the metal center. Therefore, the effect on HOMOs and LUMOs is expected to be different in P3 and P4 geometries. For both P3 and P4, the HOMO has some density on the nano-cage as well in addition to the density on the metal atom. It can probably be argued that when more than two ligands coordinate with the metal, the electron density on nickel become excess and it shits density back to the nanocage.

Next, the densities of states were analyzed to further explore the effect of nickel decoration on the electronic properties of nano-cages. The densities of states for pure and doped AlP nano-cages are compared in Figure 5. By comparison, it is observed that doping of a nickel atom causes significant shift of the occupied orbitals of AlP nano-cage to high energy levels and the newly formed HOMOs lie between the original HOMO and LUMO of AlP nano-

cage. From the comparison of Figure 5b, 5c and 5d, it is clear that nickel decoration in P1 and P2 geometry does not much affect the shape of the states rather only causes insertion of new states to shift HOMO and LUMO to new values. For P3 geometry, a number of new states appear which not only cause shift in the HOMO and LUMO but also have significant effect on the shape of the states.
The global indices of reactivity are also calculated to find out how nickel decoration affects the chemical properties of the nano-cages. The chemical potential, softness, hardness and electrophilicities of nickel decorated AlP nano-cage are reported in Table 3 and compared with pure AlP nano-cage. The energies of HOMO and LUMO play key role in deciding the global reactivity indices. The energies of HOMO and LUMO are related to the ionization potential and electron affinity, respectively, according to the Koopman theorem. The ionization potential decreases when a nickel atom is adsorbed on AlP nano-cage. The ionization potential of pure AlP nano-cage is 6.75 eV which decreases to 5.73, 5.76, 5.48 and 5.96 eV for P1, P2, P3 and P4 geometries, respectively. The electron affinity also decreases in a similar way except for P4 geometry where an increase in electron affinity is predicted. The softness of AlP nanocage increases when a nickel atom is adsorbed on the surface of the nano-cage. Since the inertness of a chemical system is inversely proportional to the softness therefore, it can be inferred that the nickel decorated AlP nano-cages are more reactive than the pure AlP nano-cage. The increase in chemical reactivity is electrophilic in nature because the electrophilicities of Ni doped nano-cages are higher than the pure nano-cage. The P4 geometry has the highest electrophilicity o f 9.13 eV followed by P3 where 8.51 eV. The electrophilicities of P1 and P2 geometries are 8.06 and 8.14 eV, respectively.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
We found that geometries of Ni decorated AlP nano-cage are very important because the electronic properties are greatly reliant the orientation of the Ni atom on the surface of the nano-cage. The high adsorption energies of Ni in all orientations are indicative of chemisorption which are dependent on the mode of interaction of Ni with the nano-cage. Based on our knowledge, for P1 and P2 orientations, only two atoms of nano-cage interact with Ni while, the number of atoms interacting with nickel increase to four and six in P3 and P4, respectively. The change in positive charge on Ni can be explained via the number and distance of coordinating atoms to the metal center. The coordination of phosphorus of the nano-cage with transition metal pushes the outer d electrons of Ni to become more diffuse excess electron which increases the energy level of newly formed HOMO. The location of densities of HOMO on metal center is supportive to our notion. Results of DOS showed that doping of a Ni atom causes significant shift of the occupied orbitals of AlP nano-cage to high energy levels and the newly formed HOMOs lie between the original HOMO and LUMO of AlP nano-cage.
